cards.resolutionDetails: The SDK was updated to properly handle null values for nullable parameters during data conversion.
cards.keyQuote: The passed value of type "null" can not be converted to required type "string"

cards.summary: Creating a Schedule without startTime and endTime fields throws a TypeError about Google\Protobuf\Timestamp. The API should allow optional start/end times, but currently fails when these fields are omitted from the ScheduleSpec.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot create schedules without explicitly providing start and end times, limiting flexibility in schedule configuration and forcing workarounds like unsetting fields.
cards.rootCause: The ScheduleSpec protobuf definition requires Timestamp fields that should be optional, causing validation errors when these fields are not provided during schedule creation.
cards.proposedFix: Make startTime and endTime truly optional in the Schedule protobuf definition and handle null/unset values properly in the serialization layer.
cards.workaround: Manually unset 'start_time' and 'end_time' keys in the ScheduleSpec constructor before calling parent::construct().
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was resolved by making the startTime and endTime fields properly optional in the protobuf schema and fixing the serialization handling.
cards.keyQuote: If startTime and endTime not declared in Schedule spec, I got this error: Uncaught Exception TypeError: "Given value is not an instance of Google\Protobuf\Timestamp."

cards.summary: Activity methods are incorrectly registered without requiring the ActivityMethod attribute, causing even constructors and magic methods to be included in the activity list. cards.proposedFix: Implement two-stage solution: (1) immediately exclude constructors and magic methods, (2) add feature flag to enforce ActivityMethod attribute requirement and trigger DeprecationError for unmarked methods.
cards.keyQuote: all methods of ActivityInterface classes are scanned and added as activity methods, instead of only registering methods with the ActivityMethod attribute only

cards.summary: react/promise v3 incompatibility causes unhandled promise rejections to trigger error_log calls with unpredictable side effects. The SDK cannot disable this behavior, and react/promise's handler mechanism is one-time rather than permanent, making the library unsuitable for async workflow coroutines until react/promise v3 is improved or a fork is created.
cards.userImpact: Users experience unpredictable error_log side effects when workflows use rejected promises without handlers, and the SDK cannot disable this react/promise v3 behavior.
cards.rootCause: react/promise v3 changed its error handling strategy to call error_log() for unhandled promise rejections, and its handler mechanism only works once rather than permanently, making it incompatible with SDK's coroutine-based workflow model.
cards.proposedFix: Temporarily revert to react/promise v2.6.1 until react/promise v3 provides a permanent (not one-time) handler mechanism, or create and maintain a Temporal-compatible fork of react/promise.
cards.workaround: Use react/promise v2.6.1 instead of v3
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue resolved by downgrading or constraining dependency to react/promise v2 compatibility; long-term solution involves either upstream react/promise improvements or maintaining a fork.
cards.keyQuote: when a rejected promise is completed, in which there is no exception handler, the error_log() function is called with the error text. The side effects of such behavior are unpredictable, and it is currently impossible to disable it.

cards.summary: Remove the DataConverter requirement from header value objects in interceptors. Headers should be decoded on input and encoded only before sending, rather than requiring DataConverter dependency for header management.
cards.userImpact: Simplifies interceptor API by removing unnecessary DataConverter dependency from header value objects, reducing coupling and improving usability.
cards.rootCause: Current implementation requires DataConverter for header value objects even when headers don't need decoding, creating unnecessary coupling.
cards.proposedFix: Decode headers immediately on input and encode them only before sending, eliminating the need to pass DataConverter to header value objects.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was addressed by refactoring header handling to avoid DataConverter requirement in header value objects.
cards.keyQuote: headers on input will be decoded immediately and packed again only before sending

cards.summary: The Doctrine Annotations library fails to parse third-party classes like Carbon\Carbon that use @mixin annotations, causing crashes when SelectiveReader is used. The SDK checks for the presence of the Reader interface and defaults to using SelectiveReader, which tries to parse incompatible annotations.
cards.userImpact: Applications using Carbon or other libraries with @mixin annotations crash during initialization when the SDK's JsonConverter, WorkerFactory, or WorkflowClient are instantiated.
cards.rootCause: SelectiveReader attempts to parse all class annotations through AnnotationReader, which fails on third-party @mixin annotations that are not imported in the scope, causing AnnotationException.
cards.proposedFix: Add a configuration option to disable SelectiveReader, or refactor to use a central reader factory method that intelligently handles annotation compatibility.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed upstream in spiral/attributes library (pull request #16), which the SDK depends on.
cards.keyQuote: if (\interface_exists(Reader::class)) { return new SelectiveReader([new AnnotationReader(), new AttributeReader()]); } - This causes Doctrine to fail parsing third-party annotations

cards.summary: Add helper methods to generate UUIDs within workflows, supporting multiple versions (v4, v7, v8) like `Workflow::uuid()` or version-specific variants. Discussion centers on whether to provide a single generic method or allow users to choose specific UUID versions.
cards.userImpact: Users will have a convenient way to generate UUIDs within workflows without manual UUID library integration.
cards.proposedFix: Implement Workflow::uuid() methods supporting UUID v4, v7, and v8, with decision between single generic method or version-specific methods (uuid4(), uuid7(), uuid8()).
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented and merged, providing UUID generation utilities for workflows.
cards.keyQuote: Add UUID sugar like `Workflow::uuid()` or `Workflow::uuid4(), ::uuid7(), ::uuid8()`

cards.summary: Update the PHP SDK dependency from reactphp/promise v2 to v3. The issue raises a question about whether v2.x should still be supported, which would require creating stubs for removed interfaces.
cards.userImpact: Ensures the PHP SDK uses the latest stable version of reactphp/promise with improved performance and security updates.
cards.proposedFix: Update reactphp/promise to v3.0.0 in composer.json and verify compatibility.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed, indicating the upgrade was completed.
cards.keyQuote: Should we support react/promise 2.x? It needs few stubs for removed interfaces

cards.summary: Feature request to define workflow return types via attributes in PHP SDK. Currently, workflow methods are limited by Generator type requirements and there's no way to unpack protobuf objects based on metadata.messageType headers.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot define custom return types for workflows or properly handle protobuf deserialization based on message type metadata.
cards.proposedFix: Add return type definition capability either to existing Workflow attribute or as a separate ReturnType attribute
cards.workaround: Use existing \Temporal\Workflow\ReturnType attribute (discovered during discussion)
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by discovering that ReturnType attribute already exists in the PHP SDK documentation
cards.keyQuote: There already is the `\Temporal\Workflow\ReturnType` attribute.

cards.summary: SideEffect callable's return type is not being respected; values are cast to string instead of the declared return type. The user expects a UuidInterface to be returned but receives a string.
cards.userImpact: Developers lose type safety when using SideEffect with callables, requiring manual type casting instead of automatic type preservation based on callable return type.
cards.rootCause: SideEffect implementation does not inspect the callable's return type annotation to properly cast the returned value.
cards.proposedFix: Implement return type inspection on the callable to automatically cast the side effect result to the declared return type.
cards.resolutionDetails: The SideEffect implementation was updated to respect callable return type declarations and cast returned values accordingly.
cards.keyQuote: In this code `$newUuid` should contain `UuidInterface` value, not string

cards.summary: Feature request to allow UUID objects to be passed directly as arguments in Temporal PHP SDK, rather than requiring them to be nested in other structures.
cards.userImpact: Users currently cannot pass UUID objects directly as workflow or activity arguments and must use workarounds to serialize them.

cards.summary: Add EnableEagerStart option to PHP SDK's StartWorkflowOptions to support Eager Workflow Dispatch (EWD), which minimizes latency from workflow start to first task processing. This feature is already available in SDK-GO v1.24.0 and needs to be implemented in the PHP SDK.
cards.userImpact: PHP developers using RoadRunner-Temporal plugin can reduce latency-sensitive workflow startup times by enabling eager workflow dispatch.
cards.proposedFix: Add EnableEagerStart boolean option to StartWorkflowOptions structure and implement mechanism to allocate workflow slot on local worker and deliver task from StartWorkflowExecutionResponse.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented to support EnableEagerStart option in StartWorkflowOptions for eager workflow dispatch capability.
cards.keyQuote: Eager Workflow Dispatch minimizes duration from starting a workflow to processing of first workflow task, making Temporal more suitable for latency sensitive applications.

cards.summary: PHP SDK client calls can hang indefinitely when the Temporal server is unreachable. The request is to add a `withTimeout()` method to the Workflow Client class to allow developers to set custom gRPC timeouts for client operations.
cards.userImpact: Applications can hang indefinitely when unable to reach the Temporal server, preventing proper error handling and recovery.
cards.rootCause: PHP gRPC client calls lack configurable timeout mechanisms, causing indefinite blocking on unreachable servers.
cards.proposedFix: Add `withTimeout(int $timeout)` method to Workflow Client class to allow setting custom timeouts for client calls.
cards.keyQuote: Currently, if the Temporal server is not reachable, the PHP client will hang forever.

cards.summary: User requests separating the Temporal PHP SDK client into a standalone package that doesn't require RoadRunner as a dependency, as they only need the client functionality without worker capabilities.
cards.userImpact: Users who only need the Temporal client are forced to install RoadRunner even though they don't use worker functionality.
cards.proposedFix: Separate the client code into a standalone package with optional RoadRunner dependency.
cards.workaround: The maintainer noted that RoadRunner doesn't need to be installed if only using the Client part.
cards.resolutionDetails: Maintainer clarified that RoadRunner is not required if only using the Client - users can simply not install it.
cards.keyQuote: Just don't install RoadRunner. You don't have to install RoadRunner if you just use Client part.

cards.summary: DataConverter throws an exception when handling null return types in activity methods. The JsonConverter rejects 'null' as an invalid type name, causing failures when activities are declared to return null.
cards.userImpact: Activities returning null values fail with DataConverterException, preventing the use of null return types in Temporal workflows.
cards.rootCause: JsonConverter.errorInvalidTypeName() rejects 'null' as a type name during deserialization, even though null is a valid PHP return type.
cards.workaround: Restart the RR server after SDK update; issue may be resolved by ensuring latest SDK version is properly loaded.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by restarting the RR server after SDK update. The root cause was likely a stale server process not using the updated SDK code.
cards.keyQuote: problem still exists... Hhm. Yep. right now it's working ðŸ˜‚

cards.summary: Add a friendly wrapper around listWorkflowExecutions that returns a lazy paginator, handling pagination automatically under the hood instead of requiring direct API calls.
cards.userImpact: Users can more easily retrieve workflow execution lists with automatic pagination handling instead of managing API calls directly.
cards.proposedFix: Wrap the listWorkflowExecutions API request and return a paginator object that implements pagination logic lazily.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented and the issue was closed.
cards.keyQuote: Wrap API request and return a paginator as result. The paginator should be lazy and implement pagination API under the hood.

cards.summary: Add support for workflow updates in the PHP SDK by making the update handler registration interface publicly available, similar to the Go SDK implementation.
cards.userImpact: PHP developers cannot implement workflow updates without access to internal update handler registration interfaces.
cards.rootCause: Update handler registration interface is internal/private and not exposed for public use in PHP SDK.
cards.proposedFix: Make the update handler registration interface publicly available in the PHP SDK, matching the Go SDK's approach of exposing internal interfaces.
cards.resolutionDetails: Update handler interface was made public in PHP SDK to support workflow updates.
cards.keyQuote: we need this interface to be publicly available to register the handler

cards.summary: Add support for worker versioning through the UpdateWorkerBuildIdCompatibility gRPC call. This allows workers to manage build ID compatibility sets for seamless deployments and versioning strategies.
cards.userImpact: Users can now manage worker versioning and build ID compatibility for controlled deployments without downtime.
cards.proposedFix: Implement UpdateWorkerBuildIdCompatibility gRPC call with support for operations: AddNewBuildIdInNewDefaultSet, AddNewCompatibleBuildId, PromoteSetByBuildId, PromoteBuildIdWithinSet, and MergeSets.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature implemented - UpdateWorkerBuildIdCompatibility gRPC call added to PHP SDK with full operation support.
cards.keyQuote: Add `UpdateWorkerBuildIdCompatibility` gRPC call to update worker buildID compatibility

cards.summary: Proto-generated PHP files cause Psalm type-checking issues that could be resolved by adding PHP annotations like @psalm-mutation-free and @psalm-assert-if-true to generated getter and hasX methods.
cards.userImpact: Developers working with proto-generated PHP files face false-positive type errors in Psalm that complicate development workflows and reduce confidence in static analysis.
cards.rootCause: Generated proto PHP files lack type-checking annotations that Psalm uses to understand null-safety semantics of hasX() and getX() method pairs.
cards.proposedFix: Add @psalm-mutation-free and @psalm-assert-if-true annotations to generated getter and hasX methods in proto PHP code generator.
cards.keyQuote: That case will be fixed if we add additional annotations in generated files like @psalm-mutation-free and @psalm-assert-if-true

cards.summary: Add support for UUID objects in the PHP SDK marshaller. Currently users must manually cast UUID objects to strings when generating, passing in activities, or receiving as results.
cards.userImpact: Users need to manually cast UUID objects to strings, adding unnecessary boilerplate code.
cards.proposedFix: Implement optional typecasters for UUID objects using ramsey/uuid or symfony/uid libraries that are only activated if the respective library is installed.
cards.workaround: Manually cast UUID objects to strings before passing to activities or returning as results.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented UUID marshaller support with optional dependency handling for ramsey/uuid library.
cards.keyQuote: Users use UUID a lot: generate like a side effect, pass in activities, get as results. Right now users must cast UUID objects to string manually.

cards.summary: Activities scheduled within signal handlers sometimes fail to execute, causing the activity to not be scheduled after the signal is delivered. This results in event history mismatches and nondeterministic errors on replay.
cards.userImpact: Workflows using activities in signal handlers experience intermittent failures where activities are not scheduled, causing NDEs and event history corruption.
cards.rootCause: Race condition or timing issue in the signal handler that prevents activities from being properly scheduled in the workflow execution context.
cards.proposedFix: Fixes were proposed in v2.5.3 and v2.5.4 to address signal handling in activity scheduling.
cards.workaround: Avoid using activities in signal handlers until the fix is verified.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixes were released in v2.5.3 and v2.5.4, though customer verification was pending due to difficulty reproducing the issue.
cards.keyQuote: sometimes the activity is not scheduled after the signal is delivered to the workflow execution... which later causes an NDE on replay

cards.summary: Feature request to add SetBinaryChecksum method to the PHP worker, allowing developers to register the binary checksum (e.g., git commit hash) with the worker for deployment rollback strategies.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot easily register binary checksums with workers, limiting their ability to implement deployment rollback strategies based on code versions.
cards.proposedFix: Add a SetBinaryChecksum method to the worker configuration API that allows setting the binary checksum during worker initialization.
cards.workaround: Use Workflow Versioning as an alternative approach to handle versioning and rollback scenarios.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed as the recommended solution is to use Workflow Versioning, which is the preferred approach for handling versioning and rollback scenarios in Temporal.
cards.keyQuote: I would like this checksum to be associated with the worker. So whenever a worker is deployed, I would like to set its checksum to with the current git ref/commit.

cards.summary: PHP 8.2 deprecated the ${var} string interpolation syntax in favor of {$var}. The Temporal PHP SDK uses the deprecated syntax, causing deprecation errors when running workflows on PHP 8.2.
cards.userImpact: Workflows fail with deprecation errors on PHP 8.2 due to incompatible string interpolation syntax in the SDK.
cards.rootCause: Temporal PHP SDK uses deprecated ${var} string interpolation syntax which was removed in PHP 8.2; replacement syntax {$var} should be used instead.
cards.proposedFix: Replace all instances of ${var} string interpolation with {$var} syntax throughout the codebase.
cards.resolutionDetails: The SDK was updated to use the modern {$var} string interpolation syntax compatible with PHP 8.2.
cards.keyQuote: Using ${var} in strings is deprecated, use {$var} instead in /project/vendor/temporal/sdk/src/Activity/ActivityCancellationType.php:66

cards.summary: CPU utilization spike observed when specific errors occur in the PHP SDK worker. The issue was resolved after upgrading from an outdated RoadRunner version to 2023.1.1, suggesting the spike was related to worker panic handling mechanisms.
cards.userImpact: Users experience significant CPU spikes when encountering specific errors in the PHP SDK worker, impacting application performance.
cards.rootCause: Outdated RoadRunner plugin version with inefficient worker panic handling mechanisms caused CPU spikes during error conditions.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade to RoadRunner version 2023.1.1 or later, which includes updated internal error handling mechanisms for temporal worker panics.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue resolved after user upgraded from RoadRunner 2.12.1 to 2023.1.1; no further spikes observed post-upgrade.
cards.keyQuote: We have updated some internal error handling mechanisms (on the temporal workers panics). These spikes are most likely due to worker restarts

cards.summary: ActivityMocker's expectCompletion() doesn't support setting different results for each activity call within a loop. Currently all calls return the same result or the entire result array is returned for each call, rather than individual results per iteration.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot properly unit test workflows that call activities in loops, limiting test coverage and forcing workarounds or more complex testing approaches.
cards.rootCause: The expectCompletion() API doesn't support per-call result specification or maintain a queue of expected results for repeated activity calls.
cards.proposedFix: Add an optional call-count parameter to expectCompletion() and expectFailure() to specify which iteration's result to mock, and maintain a queue of expected results for sequential calls.
cards.keyQuote: It will be great if we have a choice to set expectCompletion result for each call of the Activity inside the loop.

cards.summary: Protocol errors in the PHP SDK's GRPC client are not being retried, only service-level errors are. The issue requests that protocol errors be included in the retry logic for better resilience.
cards.userImpact: Applications may fail to recover from transient protocol errors that could otherwise be retried, reducing reliability.
cards.rootCause: BaseClient retry logic only handles service-level errors, not protocol-level errors from the GRPC layer.
cards.proposedFix: Include protocol errors in the retry logic alongside service-level errors.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fix was included in the next release with improved error handling and more verbose error messages for connection issues.
cards.keyQuote: protocol errors are not being retried (only service level errors) ... please retry protocol errors too.

cards.summary: User requests support for Swoole async library integration in the PHP SDK, currently limited to RoadRunner. The maintainer explains this would require porting all SDK code from Golang to C++ and maintaining two separate versions.
cards.userImpact: Users with existing Swoole-based applications cannot easily use the Temporal PHP SDK without switching to RoadRunner.
cards.rootCause: SDK is built on Golang-based async abstractions; Swoole would require porting to C++ and maintaining two separate implementations.
cards.workaround: Switch to RoadRunner as the async runtime.
cards.resolutionDetails: Maintainer decided not to support Swoole due to the significant effort required to port SDK code from Golang to C++ and maintain two separate versions.
cards.keyQuote: Porting to Swoole would mean that all of the SDK code has to be ported from Golang to C++, unfortunately, it's not just about porting async functions but a much larger scope.

cards.summary: Add a dedicated CountWorkflowExecutions API to count workflows instead of relying on the listWorkflowExecutions paginator. This is a separate API call that needs to be exposed as a distinct endpoint in the PHP SDK.
cards.userImpact: Users need an efficient way to count workflows without iterating through paginated results, improving query performance and API usability.
cards.rootCause: The paginator approach for counting workflows is insufficient; a dedicated CountWorkflowExecutions API call is needed as a separate endpoint.
cards.proposedFix: Expose CountWorkflowExecutions as a separate API endpoint in the PHP SDK, potentially supporting more than just integer responses.
cards.workaround: Use listWorkflowExecutions paginator to manually count workflows, though this is inefficient.
cards.resolutionDetails: The feature was implemented and made available in the 2.6 release with CountWorkflowExecutions as a separate API endpoint.
cards.keyQuote: The paginator isn't good enough I don't think, this is a separate `CountWorkflowExecutions` API call.

cards.summary: Worker reported memory leak with error "Got the response to undefined request" occurring in production. After investigation, the root cause was identified as misconfiguration: excessively high sticky cache size (15000) combined with PHP memory limit of 128MB, causing out-of-memory conditions rather than an actual SDK memory leak.
cards.userImpact: Workers experienced task timeouts and apparent memory leaks in production when improperly configured, affecting workflow processing reliability at scale.
cards.rootCause: Misconfigured sticky cache size (15000) with insufficient PHP memory limit (128MB) caused workers to attempt serving too many workflows in memory, triggering out-of-memory conditions and task timeouts.
cards.proposedFix: Reduce sticky cache size to match available memory and worker capacity. Set cache_size to 500, concurrent_workflows to 200, and workflow_pollers to 15. Ensure PHP memory limit accommodates the sticky cache (e.g., 500 workflows â‰ˆ 140MB).
cards.workaround: Adjust worker configuration parameters: cache_size, num_workers, and max_worker_memory to match actual resource constraints and workflow load.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was not a memory leak but a configuration error. SDK team verified no memory leaks existed in PHP codebase and provided corrected configuration settings that resolved the production issues.
cards.keyQuote: Issue number one - 'Task processing failed with error - Workflow task not found'. This issue is NOT connected to a memory leak but is related to your configuration.

cards.summary: PHP SDK has multiple bugs when running with PHP 8.2, affecting both functional and unit tests across different dependency versions and Windows platform.
cards.userImpact: Users running PHP 8.2 experience test failures and potential runtime issues with the SDK.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved, likely through compatibility fixes for PHP 8.2 support
cards.keyQuote: There are few bugs when SDK-PHP is run with PHP 8.2

cards.summary: PHP SDK should accept null for CA certificate in SSL client creation, matching gRPC's behavior. Most production servers don't need CA override as they use system-level CAs or known CAs.
cards.userImpact: Users running against production servers with standard CAs are forced to provide unnecessary CA certificate parameters, complicating client configuration.
cards.rootCause: PHP SDK requires CA certificate in createSSL while most production use cases don't need to override the default system CA.
cards.proposedFix: Accept null for CA certificate parameter in createSSL, similar to gRPC's channel credentials implementation.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue closed due to inactivity by maintainers after multiple requests for clarification went unanswered.
cards.keyQuote: Most production servers, including our cloud, don't need to override the CA as its either signed by a known CA or they install the CA root at the system level.

cards.summary: The PHP SDK needs to implement a test server downloader that uses the temporal.download service to automatically download and extract temporalite or temporal-test-server binaries based on platform, architecture, and SDK version parameters.
cards.userImpact: Users will be able to automatically download and run appropriate test servers for their platform without manual setup.
cards.proposedFix: Integrate with temporal.download API endpoint to fetch server artifacts with query parameters for platform, arch, sdk-name, and sdk-version, then extract and run the binary.
cards.keyQuote: temporal.download/{artifact_name}/{version_name} where {artifact_name} is temporalite or temporal-test-sever and {version_name} is default or a version name

cards.summary: Request to add EnumType support by default for PHP 8.1 and later versions. This would leverage PHP 8.1's native enum feature to improve type safety in the SDK.
cards.userImpact: Users on PHP 8.1+ would benefit from native enum type support, providing better type safety and IDE support.
cards.proposedFix: Add EnumType support for PHP >=8.1 by default in the SDK
cards.resolutionDetails: EnumType support was added for PHP 8.1+
cards.keyQuote: I think we should add the `EnumType` by default for PHP >=8.1

cards.summary: Worker fails to start when using a custom data converter that encrypts payloads. The worker cannot decode the encrypted workflow initialization payload, as the PHP SDK lacks support for custom payload encodings in the worker initialization process.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use custom data converters with encrypted payloads because workers fail to initialize when receiving encrypted workflow execution payloads.
cards.rootCause: The SDK's worker initialization process does not respect or support custom data converters when decoding the initial workflow definition payload, only supporting known encodings like 'json/plain' and 'binary/plain'.
cards.proposedFix: Modify the worker initialization logic to use the configured data converter when decoding payloads instead of only supporting hardcoded encodings.
cards.workaround: Check for specific workflow initialization payload structure and skip encryption for those payloads while encrypting actual workflow input/output data.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed after discussion; likely resolved through implementation of custom converter support in worker initialization or documentation of the workaround pattern.
cards.keyQuote: encoding binary/encrypted: payload encoding is not supported

cards.summary: Feature request to support nested DTOs (Data Transfer Objects) as workflow parameters. Currently, unmarshalling fails when a DTO contains another DTO as a property, causing a TypeError where stdClass is assigned instead of the expected DTO type.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use DTOs containing nested DTOs as workflow parameters, limiting the flexibility of data structures that can be passed to workflows.
cards.rootCause: The unmarshalling mechanism does not recursively deserialize nested objects into their corresponding DTO classes, instead leaving them as stdClass objects.
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was resolved by implementing support for recursive unmarshalling of nested DTOs in the serialization layer.
cards.keyQuote: Now it causes an error: TypeError: Cannot assign stdClass to property Temporal\Tests\Unit\DTO\DeepDTO\ParentDTO::$child of type Temporal\Tests\Unit\DTO\DeepDTO\ChildDTO

cards.summary: PHP 8 named arguments are incorrectly handled when calling workflow handlers, causing parameters to be passed in the wrong order. When using named arguments like `handler(bar: true)`, the SDK sends all skipped default values instead of properly mapping named arguments to their corresponding parameters.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot reliably use PHP 8 named arguments when calling workflow handlers, forcing them to use positional arguments or risk unexpected behavior.
cards.rootCause: The SDK's parameter packing mechanism does not properly handle PHP 8 named arguments, instead treating them as positional and including all default values for skipped parameters.
cards.workaround: Use positional arguments instead of named arguments when calling workflow handlers.
cards.resolutionDetails: Named arguments are not supported due to limited language support across Temporal SDKs.
cards.keyQuote: Named arguments are not allowed due to limited language support.

cards.summary: WorkflowStub methods except getResult don't properly map GRPC errors to Temporal exceptions. The cancel method and others throw generic ServiceClientException instead of domain-specific exceptions like WorkflowNotFoundException.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot reliably catch workflow-specific exceptions from most WorkflowStub methods, making error handling inconsistent and difficult.
cards.rootCause: mapWorkflowFailureToException is only called in getResult method, not applied uniformly across all WorkflowStub methods
cards.proposedFix: Apply mapWorkflowFailureToException to all WorkflowStub methods that interact with GRPC
cards.keyQuote: all methods of the WorkflowStub class, except for the getResult method, don't properly map errors from GRPC

cards.summary: Class Generator is marked as internal and final, preventing instantiation in nested child workflow scenarios. The issue occurs when deserializing workflow results that contain Generator instances returned from deeply nested child workflows.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use nested child workflows (parent -> child -> grandchild) when the deepest workflow returns a Generator, causing DataConverterException at runtime.
cards.rootCause: JsonConverter attempts to instantiate Generator class via Reflection without invoking constructor, but Generator is a final internal PHP class that cannot be instantiated this way.
cards.proposedFix: Explicitly set return type as Iterable instead of relying on Generator inference during deserialization.
cards.workaround: Explicitly declare return type as Iterable on workflow methods to avoid Generator type inference issues.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by explicitly setting return type as Iterable instead of allowing Generator type to be inferred during serialization/deserialization.
cards.keyQuote: Yes, error has if return class Generator in SubChild fixed set return type Iterable

cards.summary: Child async cancellation incorrectly propagates to parent scope, preventing further operations like timers or activity calls. The parent scope becomes marked as cancelled after cancelling a child async, causing CancelFailure errors.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot cancel child asyncs without affecting parent workflow execution, breaking expected async isolation patterns.
cards.rootCause: Parent scope is incorrectly marked as cancelled when child async is cancelled, likely due to improper scope state management during cancellation propagation.
cards.workaround: Starting an empty async after cancellation appears to reset scope state, allowing subsequent operations to work.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by implementing proper try-catch handling for cancelled child workflows; cancellation requires explicit exception handling in child scope.
cards.keyQuote: once the child is cancelled, the parent scope also becomes cancelled and thus any timer or activity call leads to CancelFailure error

cards.summary: Async batch execution in PHP SDK v2 terminates prematurely when an exception is thrown within the batch scope, causing remaining activities to complete after the workflow finishes and resulting in UnhandledCommand errors. This differs from v1 behavior where the workflow waits for batch completion.
cards.userImpact: Users experience workflow failures with UnhandledCommand errors when exceptions occur within async batch scopes, breaking expected batch completion semantics from v1.
cards.rootCause: PHP SDK v2 exits the async batch scope immediately upon exception instead of waiting for all activities to complete, unlike v1 behavior.
cards.workaround: Handle exceptions inside the scope to allow the batch to complete before exiting.
cards.resolutionDetails: Author determined this is not a bug but rather expected behavior; exceptions should be handled within the scope if batch completion is required.
cards.keyQuote: Should handle the exception inside the scope if you want the batch to be completed.

cards.summary: Remove the deprecated WorkflowExecutionTimeout field from the ContinueAsNew request in the PHP SDK. This is a cleanup task to align with API deprecations tracked in the roadrunner-temporal project.
cards.userImpact: Removes deprecated field from ContinueAsNew options, helping users write cleaner code aligned with current API standards.
cards.proposedFix: Remove WorkflowExecutionTimeout field from the ContinueAsNewOptions class in src/Workflow/ContinueAsNewOptions.php
cards.resolutionDetails: The deprecated WorkflowExecutionTimeout field was identified and removed from ContinueAsNewOptions.php
cards.keyQuote: Remove deprecated `WorkflowExecutionTimeout` field from the `ContinueAsNew` request

cards.summary: Serialization fails when a DTO class has a nullable array property (?array). The marshaller throws an InvalidArgumentException when null is passed instead of properly handling the nullable type.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot use DTOs with nullable array properties in workflow/activity arguments, forcing workarounds or restructuring their data models.
cards.rootCause: ArrayType.parse() does not handle null values for nullable array types (?array), always expecting a valid array.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed via PR #245 which was merged to handle nullable array types in serialization.
cards.keyQuote: When developer using class as DTO with public properties to pass values to workflow with property type `?array` it got an error

cards.summary: Feature request to allow custom exception classes to carry failure context information when converted to Temporal failures. Currently, ApplicationFailure must be extended directly, but the user wants to implement an interface instead to preserve custom exception context like UserExceptions and ApplicationExceptions.
cards.userImpact: Users with existing custom exception hierarchies cannot preserve context metadata when Temporal activities fail, limiting error reporting capabilities.
cards.proposedFix: Make ApplicationFailure an interface or create a FailureWithDetails/HasFailureInfo interface that custom exceptions can implement to provide details and context.
cards.keyQuote: Would be great if ApplicationFailure was an interface this way we can just force our exceptions to implement this and create details and don't have to extend ApplicationFailure all the way.

cards.summary: Feature request to extend ServiceClient::createSSL() to accept client certificates and allow server name override using gRPC options (grpc.default_authority and grpc.ssl_target_name_override).
cards.userImpact: Users cannot configure mutual TLS with client certificates or override the server name for gRPC connections, limiting secure communication options.
cards.rootCause: ServiceClient::createSSL() method lacks parameters for client certificate paths and gRPC channel options for server name override.
cards.proposedFix: Extend ServiceClient::createSSL() signature to accept client certificate paths and additional gRPC options like grpc.default_authority and grpc.ssl_target_name_override.
cards.resolutionDetails: The method was extended to support client certificates and gRPC options for server name configuration.
cards.keyQuote: But there is no way to provide client certs and override server name with `grpc.default_authority` and `grpc.ssl_target_name_override`.

cards.summary: Parent workflow with POLICY_ABANDON child close policy incorrectly waits for child workflow completion instead of abandoning it. Using yield causes parent to block, while omitting yield prevents parent from starting.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot properly implement fire-and-forget child workflows with abandon policy, breaking async patterns for background tasks.
cards.rootCause: Parent workflow incorrectly waits for child completion despite POLICY_ABANDON setting, suggesting policy is not properly applied during child workflow execution.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved in PHP SDK by properly implementing POLICY_ABANDON semantics so parent workflows don't wait for child completion.
cards.keyQuote: Having yield in the parent - it always waits for child to be completed. Without yield the parent event doesn't start.

cards.summary: User asks how to test child workflows in the PHP SDK, referencing the sample ParentWorkflow implementation. The question was redirected to Slack for community support.
cards.userImpact: Users need guidance on testing patterns for child workflows in PHP applications.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue redirected to Slack community support channel rather than being addressed as a product issue.

cards.resolutionDetails: Replayer API was implemented and exposed in the PHP SDK following the reference implementations from other SDKs.
