cards.summary: Add OpenTelemetry tracing support to the PHP SDK, built on top of interceptors. The functionality will be provided in a separate repository.
cards.userImpact: Users can instrument their Temporal workflows with OpenTelemetry tracing for better observability and monitoring.
cards.proposedFix: Implement OTEL tracing support using interceptors, following patterns from other SDKs.
cards.resolutionDetails: Functionality provided in separate repository (sdk-php-interceptors-opentelemetry) after completion of PR #313.
cards.keyQuote: The functionality will be provided in a separate repository (github.com/temporalio/sdk-php-interceptors-opentelemetry).

cards.summary: Add support for interceptors to the PHP SDK for context propagation, authorization, and instrumentation use cases, following patterns from other Temporal SDKs.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot implement cross-cutting concerns like distributed tracing, authorization checks, and context propagation in PHP workflows.
cards.proposedFix: Implement interceptor pattern following reference implementations from other Temporal SDKs.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented in version 2.7 release as indicated by comment from wolfy-j.
cards.keyQuote: Can use any of the other SDKs as reference. The main uses for interceptors are context propagation, authorization and instrumentation.

cards.summary: SDK should support both lazy and eager connection modes for the Temporal client, with lazy connections avoiding server calls and eager connections validating connectivity. Additionally, expose a gRPC health check method for users who need it.
cards.userImpact: Users can now choose between lazy connections (no server validation) and eager connections (with server validation) when creating Temporal clients, improving flexibility and reliability.
cards.rootCause: PHP SDK lacked dual connection modes and health check capabilities available in other Temporal SDKs.
cards.proposedFix: Implement lazy connection by default (PHP gRPC native behavior), add SystemInfoInterceptor for eager validation, and expose gRPC health service for client health checks.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented via SystemInfoInterceptor in v2.7.0 release which calls getSystemInfo() and getCapabilities() on first request, with option to disable by passing empty interceptor list.
cards.keyQuote: In other languages we have a lazy method to create a connection (client) that doesn't make any calls to the server, and an eager connection method that fails if getSystemInfo fails.

cards.summary: Feature request to use getSystemInfo request in the PHP SDK to determine server capabilities, allowing runtime detection of server features.
cards.userImpact: Users can dynamically determine server capabilities at runtime to adapt their workflows accordingly.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented in the 2.7.x branch
cards.keyQuote: Done in `2.7.x` branch

cards.summary: Feature request to expose workflow history length through the Workflow info object in the PHP SDK, allowing developers to access the current history size during workflow execution.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot programmatically access the workflow history length, limiting their ability to monitor and respond to history size constraints during execution.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved in version 2.7 release as indicated by the pending release comment.
cards.keyQuote: Pending 2.7 release.

cards.summary: Ensure the PHP SDK does not retry 'internal' errors that should not be retried according to gRPC error classification. Review and update the retryable client error codes list.
cards.userImpact: Users may experience unnecessary retries of operations that should fail immediately, leading to increased latency and resource consumption.
cards.rootCause: The retryable client error codes list may include 'internal' errors that should not be retried according to gRPC specifications.
cards.proposedFix: Review and correct the list of retryable client codes in BaseClient.php to exclude internal errors that should not be retried.
cards.resolutionDetails: The retryable error codes list was reviewed and updated to properly exclude internal errors.
cards.keyQuote: See the list of retryable client codes: https://github.com/temporalio/sdk-php/blob/master/src/Client/GRPC/BaseClient.php#L22

cards.summary: The PHP SDK worker needs to send sdk-name and sdk-version headers in gRPC requests, similar to what the PHP client already does. This requires implementing gRPC interceptors to override headers sent by the underlying SDK.
cards.userImpact: Without these headers, server-side telemetry and logging cannot properly identify which SDK version made requests from workers.
cards.proposedFix: Use gRPC interceptors to override the headers sent by the Go SDK
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was duplicated in roadrunner-server/roadrunner#1249
cards.keyQuote: The client already does this, needs to be implemented in the worker too.

cards.summary: Feature request for a structured API reference for the PHP SDK. The user requested an organized list of functions and APIs provided by the package, with the discussion leading to implementation of phpdoc-based documentation and deployment to php.temporal.io.
cards.userImpact: Users lack a centralized, structured reference for available PHP SDK functions and APIs.
cards.proposedFix: Use phpdoc to generate HTML API documentation and publish it to php.temporal.io via CI/CD pipeline using Vercel deployment.
cards.resolutionDetails: API documentation was generated using phpdoc and published to php.temporal.io, with implementation completed in PR #408.
cards.keyQuote: I see the docs at https://docs.temporal.io/php/introduction/ but is there a structured list of functions etc that the package provides?

cards.summary: Feature request to support readonly properties in workflow and activity input objects. Currently, properties must be set individually after object creation, which is incompatible with readonly fields.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use readonly properties in DTO classes for workflow and activity arguments, limiting their ability to use immutable patterns.
cards.rootCause: The SDK sets object properties individually after instantiation, which bypasses constructor-based initialization required for readonly properties.
cards.workaround: Avoid using readonly properties in DTO classes for workflow and activity inputs.
cards.resolutionDetails: Pull request #232 added unit tests demonstrating that readonly properties in DTOs work correctly with workflow and activity arguments.
cards.keyQuote: readonly properties in DTO's are actually work.

cards.summary: Async task declaration order in PHP SDK workflows affects execution flow incorrectly. When tasks are declared in different orders, a workflow's main async task may be rejected instead of completing successfully, depending on the order of nested async declarations.
cards.userImpact: Developers writing workflows with multiple async tasks cannot reliably control execution flow as it depends on arbitrary declaration order rather than logical semantics.
cards.rootCause: Workflow::await() does not resolve/reject correctly, causing the main async to be incorrectly rejected even when internal async tasks are canceled.
cards.proposedFix: Fix Workflow::await() to properly handle resolution and rejection states regardless of task declaration order.
cards.workaround: Ensure consistent declaration order and avoid depending on the result of the main async task.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue identified as problem with Workflow::await() resolution/rejection logic. Fix was scheduled to be released the following week.
cards.keyQuote: The problem is with `Workflow::await()`. It doesn't resolve/reject correctly. Thus the main async becomes rejected.

cards.summary: Workflow methods in PHP SDK execute activities synchronously even when not yielded, causing workflows to block waiting for activity completion despite not using the result. Activities should only execute when explicitly yielded in the workflow.
cards.userImpact: Workflows block unnecessarily on activity calls that are not yielded, causing unexpected delays and poor performance in async-designed workflows.
cards.rootCause: The PHP SDK's activity stub invocation does not defer execution until the result is yielded; instead it executes immediately and blocks the workflow.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue resolved by implementing proper lazy evaluation of activity stubs so they only execute when the result is yielded.
cards.keyQuote: Expected behavior: workflow finishes and doesn't wait for 5 seconds. Actual behavior: workflow waits for 5 seconds.

cards.summary: Signal methods with type hints for associative arrays fail because Temporal converts arrays to stdClass objects, but stdClass cannot be used as a parameter type hint. The workaround is to remove the type hint, which defeats the purpose of type safety.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot use type hints for signal method parameters that receive associative arrays, forcing them to either remove type hints or manually cast parameters.
cards.rootCause: Temporal's parameter marshaling converts associative arrays to stdClass objects, but PHP does not allow stdClass as a type hint in function signatures.
cards.workaround: Remove the type hint from the signal method parameter and rely on dynamic typing or manual casting.
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was resolved by allowing stdClass to be recognized as a valid type hint or by improving the marshaling behavior to preserve type information.
cards.keyQuote: If you pass associative array as signal parameter, Temporal converts it to \stdClass. But you cannot set \stdClass as a param type in signal's method.

cards.summary: Request to add time management interface for PHP test server, including time skipping, sleep functionality, and current time retrieval capabilities.
cards.userImpact: Users need better control over time in test environments to write more reliable and faster tests.
cards.proposedFix: Add interface methods to toggle time skipping, sleep, and retrieve current time from test server.
cards.keyQuote: Add interface to affect test server behaviour: toggle time skipping, sleep, current time retreiving

cards.summary: The PHP SDK is locked to Symfony 5, but needs to support Symfony 4, 5, and 6 versions to provide broader compatibility with different projects.
cards.userImpact: Users on projects using Symfony 4 or 6 cannot use the PHP SDK without upgrading or downgrading their Symfony version.
cards.proposedFix: Update package dependency constraints to support Symfony 4, 5, and 6 versions.
cards.resolutionDetails: Package dependency constraints were likely updated to support multiple Symfony versions.
cards.keyQuote: Need to support Symonfy 4, 5 and 6 versions.

cards.summary: When cancelling a workflow coroutine that contains an `awaitWithTimeout()` call, execution incorrectly continues to subsequent async tasks after the timeout is cancelled, instead of respecting the cancellation and stopping.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot reliably cancel workflow coroutines containing timeout operations, as code continues executing after the timeout is cancelled.
cards.rootCause: When restoring context after a cancelled timer, the code does not check whether the coroutine itself was cancelled before returning to it, allowing subsequent async tasks to execute.
cards.proposedFix: Before entering a coroutine after cancelling a timer, check whether the coroutine is cancelled and skip execution if it is.
cards.workaround: Replace `awaitWithTimeout()` with `await()` to avoid the issue, though this removes timeout functionality.
cards.keyQuote: Before entering the coroutine we should check whether it is cancelled or not.

cards.summary: Cancelling an async workflow closure with an internal timer doesn't properly cancel the timer, causing the workflow to hang indefinitely instead of finishing.
cards.userImpact: Workflows with internal timers cannot be properly cancelled, leaving them in a hung state and blocking workflow completion.
cards.rootCause: The cancellation signal is not propagated to internal timers when an async closure is cancelled.
cards.keyQuote: Expect the timer to be cancelled and workflow to be finished. Instead the workflow hangs and endlessly waits.

cards.summary: User requests a dedicated method to check if a workflow is running by ID without having to catch exceptions. Currently, the only way is to attempt getting a running workflow stub and catching WorkflowException if it fails.
cards.userImpact: Users must use exception-based error handling to determine workflow status instead of having a clean API method.
cards.workaround: Use newUntypedRunningWorkflowStub() and catch WorkflowException to determine if workflow is running
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved by implementing a dedicated method to check workflow running status
cards.keyQuote: At the moment the only possible way is to try to get a running workflow and catch an exception

cards.summary: PHP SDK does not send client info (SDK version) to Temporal via gRPC calls, preventing SDK usage metrics collection. Other SDKs already implement this feature, and the PHP SDK should support customizable client info similar to other SDKs.
cards.userImpact: Temporal cannot collect PHP SDK usage metrics, limiting observability and understanding of SDK adoption and usage patterns.
cards.proposedFix: Implement client info sending in gRPC calls following the pattern used in Go and Rust SDKs, with support for customization.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented to send client info to Temporal via gRPC calls
cards.keyQuote: Temporal has a method of collecting SDK usage metrics which relies on client sending the right SDK version and currently we're not seeing any hits from the PHP SDK.

cards.summary: Parent workflow waits for child workflow completion even when no result is yielded, preventing the parent from returning immediately after the child starts. This blocks scenarios where child workflows should execute independently without blocking the parent.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot fire-and-forget child workflows or return parent results immediately while child workflows continue running independently in the background.
cards.rootCause: PHP SDK implementation incorrectly blocks parent workflow until child workflow completion, contrary to Temporal's documented behavior that parent can return after child starts without awaiting results.
cards.proposedFix: Implement proper parent-child workflow decoupling so parent workflows can complete immediately after spawning children without waiting for child results when using non-blocking patterns.
cards.workaround: Separate child workflow logic into independent workflows and call them outside the parent workflow context.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was acknowledged and fixed in PHP SDK to allow parent workflows to return immediately without waiting for child workflow completion when results are not yielded.
cards.keyQuote: The parent workflow waits till the child starts. Once it is started the parent can be completed.

cards.summary: Two bugs found in EncodedValues: incorrect null value decoding and incorrect named argument encoding in workflows.
cards.userImpact: Users building workflow tests encounter incorrect behavior when using null values or named arguments in activities.
cards.rootCause: EncodedValues implementation has bugs in null decoding logic and named argument encoding for PHP syntax.
cards.proposedFix: PR with fixes was planned by the reporter.
cards.resolutionDetails: Bugs were fixed as indicated by the closed status and reporter's intent to create a PR.
cards.keyQuote: noticed two small bugs: wrong decoding of `null` values, wrong encoding of named arguments

cards.summary: User asks about scaling PHP SDK workers across multiple Kubernetes pods in different AWS zones. Concern about RoadRunner's internal process orchestration and potential issues with pod scaling.
cards.userImpact: Users need guidance on properly scaling PHP workers horizontally across Kubernetes clusters without architectural conflicts.
cards.rootCause: Misunderstanding that RoadRunner's internal process management is incompatible with Kubernetes pod scaling strategies.
cards.proposedFix: Use Temporal and/or RoadRunner metrics (queue_size, Temporal worker metrics) to drive cluster scaling decisions.
cards.workaround: Scale pods independently; RoadRunner manages internal processes while Kubernetes manages pod replicas.
cards.resolutionDetails: Clarified that RoadRunner works fine for pod scaling. Pods can scale independently while RoadRunner manages internal PHP processes. Use queue_size and Temporal metrics for scaling triggers.
cards.keyQuote: RoadRunner works fine for such type of scaling. It's just an application, it doesn't scale (up or down) the PHP processes, and they are constant.

cards.summary: Child worker process throws panic error "Got the response to undefined request" due to memory leak in the PHP SDK's WF worker. The issue occurs when workflows exceed cache limits and are not properly offloaded from memory, causing request tracking to become corrupted.
cards.userImpact: Users experience application crashes when scaling workflows across multiple Kubernetes pods, with panic errors disrupting workflow execution and data integrity.
cards.rootCause: When workflow cache size limit was reached, past workflows were not being completely offloaded from memory, causing request IDs to become orphaned and leading to panic errors when responses arrived for undefined requests.
cards.proposedFix: Fix in cache offloading mechanism to ensure workflows are properly removed from memory when cache limit is exceeded, particularly in awaitWithTimeout edge cases.
cards.workaround: Disable cache_size option or increase cache limits to prevent hitting the threshold, though this trades performance for stability.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed in v2.3.2 by properly collapsing awaitWithTimeout in cases when workflows are interrupted and ensuring complete memory offloading when cache limits are exceeded.
cards.keyQuote: hitting cache_limit was the reason of the leak. We were not offloading past workflow from memory completelly.

cards.summary: The SDK was using an old version of psr/log (^1.1) causing dependency conflicts with packages requiring psr/log 2.0 or 3.0. This prevented users from installing the SDK alongside other packages with newer PSR-3 logging requirements.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot install the Temporal PHP SDK in projects that depend on newer versions of psr/log, causing installation failures.
cards.rootCause: The composer.json specified a restrictive version constraint (^1.1) for psr/log instead of allowing multiple major versions.
cards.proposedFix: Use the or operator in composer.json: ^1.0|^2.0|^3.0 to allow multiple compatible major versions of psr/log.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed by merging PR #169 which updated psr/log constraint to accept multiple major versions. Released in v1.3.1.
cards.keyQuote: The SDK is using "psr/log": "^1.1" which is an old version and need to be updated, the latest version is 3.0.0 which is making conflict with other packages

cards.summary: Workflow execution sometimes fails to continue after an await condition with signals is satisfied, causing the workflow to hang indefinitely even after resending signals. The issue appears intermittently in production (~10% of cases) and couldn't be replicated in development environments.
cards.userImpact: Workflows hang unexpectedly in production when waiting for signals, requiring manual intervention and preventing process execution from resuming even after signals are resent.
cards.rootCause: Issue was in the Roadrunner (RR) version 2.10.2 and earlier, fixed in RR v2.10.3.
cards.proposedFix: Update Roadrunner to v2.10.3 and SDK to v1.3.2.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed in RR v2.10.3 and SDK v1.3.2. User confirmed stable operation after one week of running updated versions.
cards.keyQuote: It has been nearly one week running RR v2.10.3 and sdk v1.3.2 with no issues. It seems the issue has been fixed.

cards.summary: The Workflow::getVersion() method returns an EncodedValues object instead of the expected integer type, causing type comparisons to fail. Users must manually decode the result using EncodedValues::decodePromise() as a workaround.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot use Workflow::getVersion() as documented because the return type is incorrect, requiring a workaround to properly handle versioning in workflows.
cards.rootCause: Workflow::getVersion() returns an unresolved promise containing EncodedValues instead of automatically decoding to the integer type.
cards.workaround: Wrap the getVersion call with EncodedValues::decodePromise() to manually decode the result to the correct integer type.
cards.resolutionDetails: The method was fixed to properly return an integer type when yielded, resolving the type mismatch issue.
cards.keyQuote: Method call `yield Workflow::getVersion(...)` don't return integer type.

cards.summary: After worker restart, sticky execution queries and signals become unstable, causing workflow processes to be unavailable and signal handlers not to execute properly. The issue was caused by a RoadRunner version incompatibility and was resolved by updating to RR v2.10.3 and SDK v1.3.2.
cards.userImpact: Workers crash or become stuck after restart, making workflow queries and signals unreliable in production environments.
cards.rootCause: RoadRunner version incompatibility caused workflow process handles to not be properly maintained after worker restart, resulting in workflow processes being unavailable for query and signal operations.
cards.proposedFix: Update RoadRunner to v2.10.3 and SDK to v1.3.2
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed by updating to RoadRunner v2.10.3 and temporalio/sdk-php v1.3.2, which resolved the process handle management issue after worker restart.
cards.keyQuote: Workflow with the specified run identifier not found - sticky execution became unstable after worker restart causing crashes

cards.summary: Workflow timer debouncing fails when attempting to cancel and re-launch timers in response to signals. The workflow gets stuck in Running state instead of properly resetting the timer, causing roadrunner errors about undefined requests.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot implement debounce-like patterns for workflows that need to repeatedly cancel and restart timers based on signals, limiting workflow design capabilities.
cards.rootCause: The workflow execution engine has issues handling rapid timer cancellation and re-launching in awaitWithTimeout when triggered by signals, resulting in orphaned request IDs that don't match responses.
cards.workaround: Implement updatable timer logic by tracking awake time in a variable and checking it after each awakening with Workflow::timer instead of repeatedly terminating and re-launching awaitWithTimeout.
cards.keyQuote: Workflow jams in Running state instead of timer cancellation and then resetting another one.

cards.summary: Parent workflow was incorrectly waiting for child workflow completion when using POLICY_ABANDON parent close policy. The parent should only wait for the child to start, then complete independently while the child continues execution.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot spawn child workflows with abandon policy and have parent workflows complete independently, preventing asynchronous child workflow patterns.
cards.rootCause: The SDK implementation was blocking parent workflow completion until child workflow finished, contrary to the abandon parent close policy specification.
cards.proposedFix: Fix the SDK to allow parent workflow to complete once child workflow has started (ChildWorkflowExecutionStarted event appears), rather than waiting for full child completion.
cards.workaround: Use an activity with injected workflow client to spawn workflows from within activities instead of direct child workflow calls.
cards.resolutionDetails: Bug was fixed in a subsequent release (mentioned in PR #167). Users need to update to latest SDK version where parent only waits for child to start.
cards.keyQuote: The parent only waits for child to start. Once the child is started, the parent (with abandon policy) can be completed.

cards.summary: Workflow hangs indefinitely when using Workflow::await() with Promise::all() and a callback condition. The issue stems from missing yield keywords and misunderstanding of when Workflow::async() requires yield in the PHP SDK.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot implement interruptible batch operations in workflows without understanding implicit yield behavior, leading to workflows that hang or complete unexpectedly.
cards.rootCause: Missing yield keywords before Workflow::async() calls in certain contexts. The PHP SDK's implicit yield behavior for Workflow::async() in Promise::all() contexts differs from explicit yield requirements elsewhere, causing confusion about when yields are required.
cards.proposedFix: Add explicit yield keywords before all Workflow::async() calls and clarify documentation about when yield is required versus implicit.
cards.workaround: Wrap Promise::all() with Promise::any() and add explicit yield keywords before all Workflow::async() and Workflow::await() calls.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved as invalid/question - the issue was user misunderstanding of yield requirements in the PHP SDK. The workflow hangs due to missing yield keywords, not a bug in the SDK itself.
cards.keyQuote: With `Workflow::await()` and `Workflow::await()` you just create promises. To actually execute the code inside you need to call `yield`.

cards.summary: PHP documentation for WorkerInterface::registerActivity() incorrectly references ReflectionClass::getClass() method, which doesn't exist in the native PHP ReflectionClass. The correct method should be getName().
cards.userImpact: Developers following the documentation example encounter IDE errors and runtime failures when attempting to use the non-existent getClass() method.
cards.rootCause: Documentation example references ReflectionClass::getClass() which is not a method in PHP's native ReflectionClass; the intended method is getName().
cards.proposedFix: Replace getClass() with getName() in the documentation example and clarify the expected parameter format.
cards.workaround: Use $class->getName() instead of $class->getClass() to get the fully qualified class name.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed in PR #159 for the SDK and PR #1055 for official documentation.
cards.keyQuote: The primitive PHP ReflectionClass doesn't have this method. Was $class->getName() the intended method?

cards.summary: Integrate test server into the PHP SDK testing framework, similar to implementations in Java and TypeScript SDKs. This would provide a standardized way to test Temporal workflows without requiring a full server setup.
cards.userImpact: Developers can more easily test Temporal workflows in the PHP SDK with a lightweight test server, improving the testing experience and consistency across SDKs.
cards.proposedFix: Implement test server integration following the patterns established in the Java SDK (temporal-test-server) and TypeScript SDK (PR #543).
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented in the PHP SDK testing framework following the established patterns from other SDKs.
cards.keyQuote: Is blocked by https://github.com/temporalio/sdk-java/issues/1158

cards.summary: Add a finalizer mechanism to clean up resources after activity invocation, building on the stateless activities implementation.
cards.userImpact: Users can now properly manage resource cleanup after activities complete, enabling more efficient resource utilization.
cards.proposedFix: Implement a finalizer mechanism to clear resources after activity invocation
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented as indicated by the closed status and reference to prior stateless activities work
cards.keyQuote: The next step is to add an ability to clean up resources after activity is invoked.

cards.summary: Feature request to implement two new routes for handling local activities in the PHP SDK: ExecuteLocalActivity and RequestCancelLocalActivity, with corresponding handlers on the RoadRunner side.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot execute or cancel local activities in the PHP SDK, limiting functionality available in other SDKs.
cards.proposedFix: Add ExecuteLocalActivity and RequestCancelLocalActivity routes with RoadRunner-side handlers.
cards.resolutionDetails: Routes were implemented to support local activity execution and cancellation.
cards.keyQuote: We need to support two new routes: `ExecuteLocalActivity` and `RequestCancelLocalActivity`.

cards.summary: PHPDoc type hints are incorrectly specified for typed arguments in ServiceContainer, causing Psalm static analysis to fail with type mismatch errors.
cards.userImpact: Developers using Psalm for static analysis encounter false type errors, hindering code quality checks and IDE support.
cards.rootCause: PHPDoc blocks for typed arguments conflict with actual type declarations, causing Psalm to report incorrect type mismatches.
cards.proposedFix: Remove PHPDoc type hints for arguments that have native PHP type declarations.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved by removing redundant PHPDoc type hints for typed parameters.
cards.keyQuote: It would be great don't use phpdoc blocks for typed arguments.

cards.summary: Protobuf messages returned from CRON scheduled workflows cannot be decoded when fetching previous results via Workflow::getLastCompletionResult(). The issue was resolved by explicitly declaring the return type using the #[ReturnType] attribute.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot retrieve protobuf-encoded results from CRON scheduled workflows without explicitly specifying the return type.
cards.rootCause: The DataConverter cannot properly decode protobuf values without explicit type information provided via the #[ReturnType] attribute.
cards.proposedFix: Add explicit #[ReturnType(ClassName::class)] attribute to the WorkflowInterface method definition.
cards.workaround: Use the #[ReturnType] attribute on workflow methods that return protobuf messages and access the result object via type-safe getters.
cards.resolutionDetails: User confirmed that adding explicit #[ReturnType] attribute to the workflow method resolved the decoding issue.
cards.keyQuote: Try to do the following: In your WorkflowInterface add explicit attribute for the return type

cards.summary: Workflows remain in running state until all async coroutines complete or are manually cancelled, even after the workflow reaches a return/exception condition. This is intended behavior but can be inconvenient when managing long-running activities with async completion.
cards.userImpact: Users may struggle to cleanly terminate workflows with unfinished async coroutines without manually cancelling each scope.
cards.rootCause: Async coroutines intentionally block workflow return until they complete or are cancelled; this is by design rather than a bug.
cards.workaround: Manually call cancel() on async scopes before workflow return to allow graceful termination without waiting for activities to complete.
cards.resolutionDetails: Confirmed as intended behavior. Team advised updating documentation to clarify that cancellation can be triggered from inside workflows and should be used for cleanup.
cards.keyQuote: Async coroutines will block the return from the workflow until they are complete or canceled. It's intended behavior.

cards.summary: Add metadata.messageType field to protobuf payloads in PHP SDK to match Java and Go SDK implementations. This requires accessing the protobuf message's full name/type information.
cards.userImpact: Users can include message type metadata in protobuf payloads for better interoperability and debugging across Temporal SDKs.
cards.rootCause: PHP Protobuf library's DescriptorPool API not initially discoverable for accessing message full names.
cards.proposedFix: Use DescriptorPool::getGeneratedPool()->getDescriptorByClassName($value::class)->getFullName() to extract message type.
cards.resolutionDetails: Solution provided in comment showing how to access message type using Google Protobuf's DescriptorPool API.
cards.keyQuote: To get message type you can use the following: $pool = \Google\Protobuf\Internal\DescriptorPool::getGeneratedPool(); $pool->getDescriptorByClassName($value::class)->getFullName();

cards.summary: The awaitWithTimeout workflow utility does not immediately resume when the condition becomes true; instead, it waits for the full timeout duration to elapse before checking again. This causes workflows to hang until the timeout expires rather than responding promptly to signal-triggered state changes.
cards.userImpact: Workflows receiving signals do not resume execution immediately, causing unexpected delays in workflow completion and making signal-based control flow unreliable.
cards.rootCause: The awaitWithTimeout implementation does not interrupt the timeout when the awaited condition becomes true; it only checks the condition after the timeout expires.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was fixed by modifying awaitWithTimeout to interrupt the timeout when the condition evaluates to true rather than waiting for the full duration.
cards.keyQuote: Run the workflow, send `cancel` signal, workflow stays running. Only after timeout (600 seconds) it completes with result `CANCEL`.

cards.summary: Workflow with awaitWithTimeout and signal handlers exhibits timing issues where timeout completion doesn't trigger properly when signals are sent, causing workflows to remain stuck until the opposite condition occurs.
cards.userImpact: Workflows using awaitWithTimeout with signals become unresponsive and require manual intervention or waiting for timeouts, preventing proper workflow execution flow.
cards.rootCause: Race condition between timeout expiration and signal handler updates affecting workflow state evaluation
cards.resolutionDetails: Bug was resolved through fixes to the workflow coordination and signal handling mechanism
cards.keyQuote: Run the workflow, after 30 seconds it still stays running. If after that I send cancel signal, workflow completes with result `OK`.

cards.summary: Activity code sometimes fails to execute when the same activity method is called multiple times with different arguments inside a workflow, despite showing as completed in history. Workaround is to use different method names for each activity call.
cards.userImpact: Activities fail to execute silently when called multiple times by name in a workflow, causing unpredictable behavior despite successful history records.
cards.rootCause: Likely activity name-based deduplication or caching mechanism incorrectly preventing subsequent calls to the same activity method from executing.
cards.workaround: Use different method names for each activity call instead of reusing the same method name with different arguments.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue closed by reporter due to no feedback, likely due to inactivity rather than confirmation of fix.
cards.keyQuote: It might be because of the same activity name method... When changed the code to use different method names it worked

cards.summary: PHP SDK workers cannot be configured to listen to a specific namespace, only to the default namespace. This prevents workers from processing tasks in non-default namespaces when clients are created with different namespace options.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot configure workers to listen to non-default namespaces, breaking multi-namespace deployments and requiring manual .rr.yaml configuration workarounds.
cards.rootCause: PHP SDK WorkerOptions lacks namespace configuration support that exists in other SDKs like Go, requiring manual RoadRunner configuration instead.
cards.proposedFix: Add namespace support to WorkerOptions similar to WorkflowClient, allowing workers to be configured with a specific namespace during creation.
cards.workaround: Manually edit the .rr.yaml RoadRunner configuration file to set the namespace for workers.
cards.resolutionDetails: Namespace support was included in v2.6.1 RoadRunner release, providing the necessary configuration capability in the generated .rr.yaml file.
cards.keyQuote: Creating a worker only listens to the `default` namespace. How can we avoid that?

cards.summary: Add a built-in "listQueries" query capability to the PHP SDK, tracking the feature request from the cross-SDK features issue.
cards.userImpact: Users can query available queries on a workflow to improve runtime introspection capabilities.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented to match other SDK implementations of the listQueries built-in query.
cards.keyQuote: See original issue: temporalio/sdk-features#51

cards.summary: When a PHP worker is started with session support enabled via `withEnableSessionWorker(true)`, user-registered activities cannot be found and cause ActivityNotRegisteredError. Only internal session activities are visible to the workflow.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot execute user-defined activities when using session workers in PHP SDK, blocking the use of sessions for activity execution patterns.
cards.rootCause: Session worker implementation was exposed in configuration before full implementation was complete. User activities are not properly registered alongside internal session activities.
cards.workaround: Use separate task queues for workers instead of session workers, as demonstrated in PHP SDK examples.
cards.keyQuote: it's semi-bug at the moment since we exposed the configuration option for sessions ahead of the actual implementation

cards.summary: After workflow restart via continueAsNew, awaitWithTimeout condition evaluation fails and waits for the full timeout instead of detecting when the condition becomes true. The await predicate appears to not be re-evaluated after workflow continuation.
cards.userImpact: Workflows cannot efficiently resume after continueAsNew when waiting for conditions updated via signals, forcing users to wait for timeouts instead of resuming immediately.
cards.rootCause: awaitWithTimeout predicate not being re-evaluated after workflow restart via continueAsNew, likely due to closure or state reference issues in the condition lambda.
cards.resolutionDetails: Addressed in version 1.0.5 according to comment by repository maintainer.
cards.keyQuote: after workflow "restart" via continueAsNewStub seems that condition never goes to true

cards.summary: User inquires about the availability of activity_task_schedule_to_start_latency metrics in the PHP SDK, expecting it to be present since the PHP SDK is built on top of the Go SDK which implements these metrics.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot monitor activity scheduling latency metrics in PHP SDK, limiting observability into workflow performance.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed due to inactivity by maintainer after clarification question was asked.
cards.keyQuote: I can't activity_task_schedule_to_start_latency metrics on php-sdk. Is it not implemented yet?

cards.summary: Activity returning associative arrays are deserialized as stdClass objects instead of arrays in workflow promises, causing type errors when accessing array values. The issue stems from JSON deserialization behavior that treats associative arrays as objects.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot reliably use activity results containing associative arrays in workflow promises, requiring workarounds like using DTOs instead of native arrays.
cards.rootCause: JsonConverter deserialization converts associative arrays to stdClass objects due to JSON format not distinguishing between arrays and objects.
cards.workaround: Use Data Transfer Objects (DTOs) instead of associative arrays for activity return values.
cards.resolutionDetails: Marked as duplicate of issue #93. Behavior is documented and working as designed; users should use DTOs for consistent typing.
cards.keyQuote: This is not a bug (More precisely, this is documented behavior). Please use DTO instead.

cards.summary: Stack trace from workflow failures shows incorrect line numbers pointing to the workflow method call site instead of the actual activity method invocation, and the correct stack trace is stored in an inaccessible originalStackTrace property rather than the standard trace property.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot properly debug workflow failures because stack traces point to incorrect locations and the useful information is hidden in a non-standard property.
cards.rootCause: PHP does not allow overwriting exception traces at runtime like Java does, so the SDK stores the correct trace in originalStackTrace instead of the standard trace property.
cards.proposedFix: Train exception renderers (like Sentry) to recognize and display the originalStackTrace property from Temporal exceptions.
cards.workaround: Manually inspect the originalStackTrace property when debugging workflow failures.
cards.resolutionDetails: Determined to be expected behavior due to PHP language limitations. The correct trace is stored in originalStackTrace as a workaround since PHP doesn't allow overwriting exception traces.
cards.keyQuote: Unfortunately, it is not possible to overwrite the PHP exception trace as it possible in Java. So the only option was to include it into the originalStackTrace.

cards.summary: Feature request to replace Carbon library with DateInterval for better performance. Discussion reveals Carbon is only used internally and public APIs already use standard DateTimeInterface and DateInterval, making the replacement feasible.
cards.userImpact: Replacing Carbon with DateInterval could reduce latency in time-related operations, potentially saving ~0.00003s per I/O operation.
cards.rootCause: Carbon library has performance overhead compared to native DateInterval, particularly in hot spots like sending local temporal time to server (4x slower) and parsing time from temporal server (4x slower).
cards.proposedFix: Replace Carbon with native DateInterval implementation in internal hot spots while keeping public APIs using standard DateTimeInterface and DateInterval.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue closed due to inactivity.
cards.keyQuote: It's slower than DateInterval. Very slower.

cards.summary: Parent workflow gets stuck in running state when starting a child workflow fails due to the child workflow ID already existing. The parent workflow should either complete or fail, but instead remains indefinitely in running state until timeout.
cards.userImpact: Workflows become stuck indefinitely when attempting to start a child workflow with a duplicate ID, requiring manual intervention or timeout to resolve.
cards.rootCause: The workflow engine does not properly handle START_CHILD_WORKFLOW_EXECUTION_FAILED events, leaving the parent workflow in an incomplete state instead of transitioning to completed or failed status.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed in roadrunner-temporal PR #77
cards.keyQuote: Workflow instance will stuck at running, and the last event is WorkflowTaskCompleted until it timeout.

cards.summary: User asked why arrays cannot be used as return types in activity methods. The limitation exists because PHP lacks generic type hints for composite types, and JSON's lack of hash maps creates ambiguity in type serialization.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot directly return arrays from activity methods and must wrap data in DTO objects instead.
cards.rootCause: PHP does not support generic type hints (e.g., array<string, string>) and JSON cannot represent PHP associative arrays as hash maps, creating ambiguity in serialization.
cards.workaround: Use Data Transfer Objects (DTOs) to wrap composite data instead of returning arrays directly.
cards.resolutionDetails: This is a language limitation acknowledged by maintainers. The recommended approach is to use DTOs for transferring composite data.
cards.keyQuote: Recommended to use DTOs to transfer composite data between code.

cards.summary: User asks how to inject configuration into workflow constructors, as workflows must be instantiated without arguments. Discussion reveals workflows must be deterministic and suggests using signals, activities, or side-effects for dependency injection.
cards.userImpact: Developers need guidance on how to pass configuration to workflows while maintaining determinism, a common pattern in legacy system migrations.
cards.rootCause: Workflows require deterministic instantiation without constructor arguments to maintain replay consistency, creating tension with common DI patterns.
cards.proposedFix: Use signals, activities, or local activities to pass configuration data into workflows deterministically, with local activities being the preferred long-term solution.
cards.workaround: Load configuration via activity calls within the workflow, or use startWithSignal to inject config at workflow start time, or use side-effects for file-based config.
cards.resolutionDetails: User resolved their own confusion by understanding Temporal's determinism requirements and implementing configuration loading via activities.
cards.keyQuote: Local Activities are planned in the 1.1 version of this SDK... workflow fully controls its config and does not expose anything to the outside.

cards.summary: User requests ability to inject a custom reader into WorkerFactory to support gradual migration from legacy annotation-based workflow/activity registration to Temporal attributes. Current implementation uses final classes, preventing subclassing and customization.
cards.userImpact: Users migrating from legacy systems cannot gradually transition to Temporal attributes without reimplementing the entire WorkerFactory.
cards.rootCause: WorkerFactory and related classes are declared as final, preventing subclassing and customization of the reader selection logic.
cards.proposedFix: Add ReaderInterface as an optional parameter to WorkerFactory::create() method, similar to how DataConverterInterface is already handled. Make createReader() method protected or allow dependency injection via constructor.
cards.workaround: Copy the entire WorkerFactory implementation to customize the reader selection logic.
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was closed after the user agreed to submit a PR addressing the feature request.
cards.keyQuote: The best option of course would be if I could override the default reader with my own through constructor, just like it's done with DataConverter currently.

cards.summary: User asks whether PHP SDK supports timeout settings when waiting for signals in workflows. The question is resolved by pointing to the awaitWithTimeout function.
cards.userImpact: Users need to know the correct API to use when they want to wait for signals with a timeout.
cards.proposedFix: Use awaitWithTimeout function or await with signal and custom timer.
cards.workaround: Use custom timer alongside await with signal.
cards.resolutionDetails: User was directed to use awaitWithTimeout function which provides the requested timeout functionality.
cards.keyQuote: try to use awaitWithTimeout or use await with signal and custom timer

cards.summary: When using `continueAsNew` to restart a workflow, the workflow type name is incorrectly passed as a fully-qualified class name instead of the registered short name, causing the worker to fail with 'unable to find workflow type' errors.
cards.userImpact: Users attempting to implement self-restarting workflows using continueAsNew encounter worker failures and unable to resume workflow execution.
cards.rootCause: The continueAsNew method appears to be using the fully-qualified class name (FQDN) instead of the short registered workflow type name when continuing the workflow.
cards.workaround: Replace generator-based workflow type collection with an array-based collection in the registry, though the root cause remains unclear.
cards.resolutionDetails: Reporter could not reproduce the issue with latest versions and closed it. The workaround worked but root cause was never definitively identified.
cards.keyQuote: unable to find workflow type: Application\BusinessProcess\ZeroBalance\ZeroBalanceWorkflow. Supported types: [ZeroBalanceWorkflow]

cards.summary: A bug in the RetryOptions setter where the maximum interval parameter incorrectly sets the initial interval instead. This causes incorrect retry behavior for activities.
cards.userImpact: Activities use incorrect initial retry intervals, causing unpredictable retry behavior in production workflows.
cards.rootCause: The setter for maximum interval in RetryOptions.php line 172 incorrectly assigns the value to the initial interval property instead of the maximum interval property.
cards.proposedFix: Fix the setter to correctly assign the maximum interval parameter to the maximum interval property.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed and released in v1.0.3
cards.keyQuote: setter for maximum interval sets the initial interval

cards.summary: Child workflows are not automatically inheriting the parent workflow's namespace, requiring manual propagation despite documentation suggesting it should work automatically. This breaks custom namespace configurations until explicitly passed through ChildWorkflowOptions.
cards.userImpact: Users working with custom namespaces (especially Temporal Cloud) must manually propagate namespace to child workflows or use interceptor workarounds, breaking expected inheritance behavior.
cards.rootCause: ChildWorkflowOptions initializes namespace to ClientOptions::DEFAULT_NAMESPACE instead of inheriting the parent workflow's current namespace context.
cards.proposedFix: Modify ChildWorkflowOptions to automatically inherit the parent workflow's namespace when not explicitly specified, similar to how TaskQueue is already being transferred.
cards.workaround: Manually pass namespace through workflow parameters or use a WorkflowOutboundRequestInterceptor to set namespace on all child workflow requests.
cards.resolutionDetails: The fix ensures namespace is inherited from parent workflow context even when users don't explicitly specify it in ChildWorkflowOptions.
cards.keyQuote: Namespace should be inherited even when the user has specified options for a ChildWorkflow that don't include a custom Namespace value.

cards.summary: User seeks best practices for integrating Sentry error logging with Temporal PHP SDK, asking whether a global error handler exists to catch errors from workflows and activities, or if integration with RoadRunner is possible.
cards.userImpact: Users lack a standardized way to integrate Sentry for centralized error logging across activities and workflows, requiring manual try-catch and logging in each activity.
cards.rootCause: The SDK does not provide a built-in global error handler or PSR-3 logger injection mechanism for activities, requiring users to implement error handling manually.
cards.proposedFix: Implement container refactoring with activity call interception capability to catch exceptions globally, or make SDK properties protected for extension.
cards.workaround: Intercept activity calls using a custom router (e.g., InvokeActivityRouter) or extend WorkerFactory, though this requires accessing private fields and is considered hacky.
cards.keyQuote: The container refactor planned later this year, with some internal changes and optimizations, including the ability to intercept activity call (for exception catching or state resets).

cards.summary: Request to implement GetSearchAttributesRequest in PHP SDK to enable programmatic workflow and activity search similar to Java SDK. User needs this for writing integration tests that check workflow states without relying on shell commands.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot programmatically search workflows and activities in PHP SDK, forcing them to use shell commands or manual gRPC requests for integration testing.
cards.proposedFix: Implement a search API wrapper similar to Java SDK that abstracts gRPC complexity and provides a user-friendly interface for searching workflows and activities.
cards.workaround: Use manual gRPC requests or create a user-defined gRPC wrapper, or use shell_exec to call tctl commands.
cards.resolutionDetails: Maintainer decided to defer implementation pending resolution of other backlog items. Recommended users use gRPC wrappers or tctl as interim solution.
cards.keyQuote: It would be sufficient to get the same functionality as in the java sdk

cards.summary: PHP 7.4 docblock annotations were not recognized by the SDK, which only supported PHP 8 attributes. The client would throw an error claiming the required attribute was missing even when using docblock-style annotations that should be compatible with the minimum supported PHP 7.4 version.
cards.userImpact: Users targeting PHP 7.4 could not use the SDK with docblock-style annotations, forcing them to upgrade to PHP 8 or switch to attribute syntax despite the declared minimum version support.
cards.rootCause: The WorkflowClient only supported PHP 8 attributes and did not fall back to parsing docblock-style annotations, despite PHP 7.4 being the minimum supported version in composer.json.
cards.proposedFix: Add docblock annotation parsing support to WorkflowClient (similar to the implementation that likely existed elsewhere in the SDK).
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed in SDK 1.0.2+ by adding docblock annotation support to the WorkflowClient, likely mirroring existing implementation patterns used in other parts of the codebase.
cards.keyQuote: the SDK is unable to parse my workflows because I'm not using PHP 8 style attributes, but older PHP 7.4 docblock style

cards.summary: RetryOptions' non-retryable exceptions list doesn't work due to incorrect type checking logic. The code uses `instanceof` on class name strings instead of `is_subclass_of()`, causing assertion errors when retrying non-retryable exceptions.
cards.userImpact: Activities fail with AssertionError instead of being retried or failing properly when non-retryable exceptions are configured.
cards.rootCause: The `Temporal\Internal\Assert::valuesSubclassOf` method uses `instanceof` operator on class name strings instead of using `is_subclass_of()` function to check exception hierarchy.
cards.proposedFix: Replace `instanceof` checks with `is_subclass_of()` function calls to properly validate class name string hierarchy.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed in PR #96
cards.keyQuote: The problem is with the `Temporal\Internal\Assert::valuesSubclassOf` method. PHP's `instanceof` won't work here: $v instanceof $of returns false because $v is just a string

cards.summary: User unable to access Laravel facades inside Temporal workflows and activities due to missing facade context. Received RuntimeException when attempting integration with Laravel 8.x.
cards.userImpact: Users integrating Temporal with Laravel cannot use Laravel facades in workflows and activities without encountering runtime errors.
cards.rootCause: Laravel facade context is not available in Temporal workflow and activity execution contexts, which run outside the normal Laravel request lifecycle.
cards.proposedFix: Use Laravel commands or other facade-safe contexts for workflow/activity setup. Avoid facades in workflows to preserve determinism; use them only in activities.
cards.workaround: Execute Temporal workflows and activities inside Laravel command context where facade context is already established.
cards.resolutionDetails: User confirmed the workaround of using Laravel commands resolved the issue. Recommendation to avoid facades in workflows for determinism was accepted.
cards.keyQuote: I would recommend starting working inside laravel command, where facade context is already set. However, I'd like to also recommend avoid using facades in Workflows, they might break the determinism of that code.

cards.summary: Activity methods returning PHP associative arrays are deserialized as stdClass objects in workflows, causing 'Cannot use object as array' errors. Users need to explicitly cast the result back to an array or use DTOs instead.
cards.userImpact: Developers returning associative arrays from activities cannot use them as arrays in workflows without explicit casting or restructuring their code.
cards.rootCause: JSON protocol used for inter-service communication converts PHP associative arrays to JSON objects, which are deserialized as stdClass objects rather than arrays.
cards.proposedFix: Explicitly cast the result: (array)(yield $simple->getAssocArray($input)) or use proper DTOs with public properties for type safety.
cards.workaround: Cast returned objects to arrays using (array) typecast, or refactor to use Data Transfer Objects (DTOs) with public properties.
cards.resolutionDetails: Limitation of JSON transport protocol. Users advised to use explicit casting or DTO approach instead of associative arrays for inter-service communication.
cards.keyQuote: when packing such data into this format, the types are converted from a hash-map to an object... this is not a bug, but rather a limitation of the transport protocol

cards.summary: Remove unnecessary files from the PHP SDK composer package before release to reduce package size and distribution footprint. Files like tests, build configuration, and development tools should be excluded.
cards.userImpact: Reduces the PHP SDK package size and removes unnecessary development files from end-user installations.
cards.proposedFix: Exclude development and test directories from the composer package configuration (likely via .gitattributes or composer.json export-ignore)
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved via pull request #91 which implemented the exclusion of specified files from the composer package
cards.keyQuote: Before release, we need to exclude a set of files from the composer package

cards.summary: The service container and worker factory classes need to be rewritten with a clearer, more user-friendly approach, potentially using PSR-11 standard. This refactoring should address design issues and consider that these services are also used in the client.
cards.userImpact: Users experience an unclear and less user-friendly service container API that could be simplified through PSR-11 standard compliance.
cards.rootCause: The current service container implementation lacks clarity and doesn't follow standard patterns; the design needs improvement for both worker and client use cases.
cards.proposedFix: Rewrite service container and worker factory using PSR-11 standard for a clearer, more user-friendly approach.
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed because the current structure is stable and sufficient for current needs.
cards.keyQuote: Should be rewritten using a clearer and more user-friendly approach (global PSR-11?).

cards.summary: Request to add upsert Search Attribute functionality to the PHP SDK. The team confirmed this would be implemented after the release as a quick addition.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot update search attributes for running workflows in the PHP SDK, limiting workflow discoverability and metadata management capabilities.
cards.proposedFix: Implement upsert Search Attribute API in PHP SDK following patterns from other SDKs
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented in the PHP SDK after the release as planned by the maintainers
cards.keyQuote: We will add upsert attribute after the release, it's quick to do.

cards.summary: User unable to establish a connection to the Temporal Server at tcp://127.0.0.1:6001 when attempting to execute workflows. This was an early adoption issue during the PHP SDK beta phase before official release and documentation were available.
cards.userImpact: Early adopters were unable to set up and run workflows due to incomplete documentation and unreleased SDK components.
cards.rootCause: PHP SDK was still in beta/development phase. The Roadrunner-Temporal integration required building from master branch with go-sdk master, and PHP GRPC extension was required but not clearly documented.
cards.proposedFix: Users needed to build Roadrunner-Temporal from master branch with go-sdk master branch, ensure go.mod points correctly, and install PHP GRPC extension. Alternatively, wait for official release with pre-built binaries and comprehensive documentation.
cards.workaround: Users could build from master branch following the test instructions provided, or wait for the official release which would include Roadrunner by default in composer packages.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by the official PHP SDK release with improved documentation and pre-built Roadrunner-Temporal support, making setup no longer require manual compilation.
cards.keyQuote: Obviously, we will try to make it as easy as possible after finishing the release. With no need to build anything, we plan RR to include Temporal by default and be downloadable via composer.

cards.summary: PHP SDK needs DTO comparison and alignment with Java/Go SDKs. Document differences in structure for ChildWorkflowOptions, RetryPolicy, WorkflowInfo, ActivityInfo and other data transfer objects, and identify missing fields like contextPropagators, cancellationType, and getRunStartedTimestampMillis().
cards.userImpact: Inconsistent DTO structures between PHP and Java/Go SDKs make it harder for developers to work across multiple SDK languages and may cause integration issues.
cards.rootCause: PHP SDK development proceeded independently without full alignment with Java/Go SDK DTOs, resulting in missing fields and structural differences.
cards.proposedFix: Align PHP DTO definitions with Java/Go counterparts by adding missing fields like contextPropagators, cancellationType, getRunStartedTimestampMillis(), and ensuring consistent field naming and structure.
cards.workaround: Binary checksum capability already exists in Version.php and needs to be exposed to Go SDK.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue tracked and addressed through DTO alignment efforts; missing fields identified and alignment with Java/Go SDKs completed.
cards.keyQuote: Expose long getRunStartedTimestampMillis(), activity start to close and schedule to close timeout. Need to align DTO structures with Java and Go SDKs.

cards.summary: Implement cancellation scopes functionality for the PHP SDK, including support for nested scopes, hierarchical cancellation, and comprehensive testing of cancellation behavior across various scenarios.
cards.userImpact: Users can now properly manage cancellation within workflows using nested scopes, enabling fine-grained control over which parts of their workflow logic respond to cancellation signals.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature fully implemented with comprehensive testing covering execution, cancellation, nested scopes, hierarchical cancellation, nested scope cancellation, coroutine stack checks, and other edge cases.
cards.keyQuote: Implement functionality, Testing (Implement testing API) - Execution, Cancellation, Nested scopes, Hierarchical cancellation, Canceling a nested scope, Coroutine stack checks, Other cases

cards.keyQuote: this SDK does have a Workflow client - Worker (we use different name due to different execution strategy)

cards.summary: User asks whether the PHP SDK can work standalone without RoadRunner for launching workflows and receiving activities. Initial attempts to connect directly to Temporal server fail with protocol errors.
cards.userImpact: Users with existing PHP stacks need to know if they can use Temporal SDK as a standalone client or if RoadRunner is a hard dependency.
cards.rootCause: Early SDK version required RoadRunner for communication; later versions added gRPC support but with caveats around worker implementation
cards.proposedFix: Support launching workflows from PHP without RoadRunner by using gRPC endpoints directly; eventually provide Java-like Workflow and Activity clients with better abstraction
cards.workaround: Use proto-generated PHP gRPC client directly instead of the SDK wrapper
cards.resolutionDetails: SDK evolved to support gRPC-based WorkflowService for launching workflows without RoadRunner; workers still require supervisor but client-only use cases are supported
